channel.title: NYT > Style
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Was the World’s Best Kisser’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Ayo Edebiri and Her Dog Gromit Go to the Bookstore
item.description: A morning out in Los Angeles with the surprise star of “The Bear” and her Chihuahua mix.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Angotti-Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: The writer, actress and comedian Ayo Edebiri at Skylight Books in Los Angeles.

item.title: What Is the Jellyfish Haircut?
item.description: A Nicole Kidman photo shoot renewed interest in a hairstyle that looks like an avant-garde cousin of the mullet.
item.media:credit: Mari Trombley
item.media:description: Mari Trombley relishes making eye-catching changes to her hair, including the bold jellyfish cut she gave herself this summer.

item.title: Who Is Quiet Quitting For?
item.description: For those not ready to make a grand exit, a softer approach may work.
item.media:credit: Anthony Redpath – Getty Images

item.title: Dancing Up a Political Storm
item.description: The prime minister of Finland was caught on the dance floor. This is a bad thing?
item.media:credit: Matias Honkamaa/Agence France-Presse, via Lehtikuva/AFP via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanna Marin of Finland.

item.title: She Went From Being a ‘Hermit’ Jeweler to a Museum Curator
item.description: Emefa Cole first exhibited her bold, sculptural jewelry at a craft fair. Now she’s taking on a new role at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London.
item.media:credit: Serena Brown for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emefa Cole on the steps of the Victoria & Albert Museum. She is the museum’s first curator of jewelry for the diaspora.

item.title: Serena Williams’s Fashion Smash
item.description: The game-changing tennis player used her clothes as a statement of self and a weapon of change.

item.title: Should I Try to Hide My Large Bandage at Work?
item.description: A reader wonders how to dress after a recent medical procedure.
item.media:credit: Daniele Venturelli/Getty Images
item.media:description: Lila Moss Hack on the runway at a Versace show in Milan, with her insulin pump visibly attached to her thigh.

item.title: One of This Movie’s Stars: A Really Big Emerald
item.description: “Inside the Dream” tells the story of a Bulgari necklace with a 93.83-carat gem.
item.media:credit: Stephane Cardinale/Getty Images
item.media:description: Zendaya walks the red carpet for “Dune” at the 2021 Venice International Film Festival in Venice, Italy. She was wearing the Magnifica Hypnotic Emerald necklace by Bulgari.

item.title: Fentanyl Test Strips Are ‘Catching On’ Among Cocaine Users
item.description: A rise in overdoses have prompted some drug users to make testing a party ritual.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westhoff
item.media:credit: Mark Lennihan/Associated Press

item.title: Parents Are Hiring Babysitters or the ‘Disco Nanny’ for a Night Out
item.description: In party hot spots around Europe, agencies have popped up to provide child care at all hours of the night and day.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger

item.title: Edward Enninful Also Wears Prada
item.description: The star fashion editor has reinvented British Vogue and written a memoir. What’s his next act?
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Serena Brown for The New York Times
item.media:description: Edward Enninful in London in July.

item.title: How Quitting a Job Changed My Relationships
item.description: We asked people who quit during the “Great Resignation” how it helped them reconnect with their loved ones. This is what they told us.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Leah Nash for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ana del Rocío with her sons, Tupac, left, and Inti, at their home in Portland, Ore. Ms. del Rocío left her job as executive director of a nonprofit to spend more time with her children.

item.title: Leaving Los Angeles
item.description: Hollywood wasn’t exactly the Hollywood you see in movies.
item.dc:creator: Annie Hamilton

item.title: ‘September Is the New May’ When It Comes to Planting Flowers
item.description: Your garden may not be looking Instagram ready at the moment, but don’t give up: There’s time for more color before the first frost.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Roach

item.title: One White Street’s TriBeCa Farm Stand Draws Celebrity Customers
item.description: Open only on Tuesdays, the restaurant One White Street’s seasonal farm stand has become a reliable place to spot famous faces.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Barnard
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Bick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers young and old peruse the selection of produce and other goods at the farm stand on the corner of White Street and West Broadway in TriBeCa.

item.title: Don’t Get Dressed Without Reading This Book
item.description: Claire McCardell helped create American fashion. She was also a writer whose book on style still resonates today.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: Jenifer Lewis Is Back on Her Grind With a New Book and ‘I Love That for You’
item.description: With a new Showtime series and book of essays, the veteran actress, who relishes her real-life role as everybody’s auntie, is enjoying her flowers.
item.dc:creator: Gina Cherelus
item.media:credit: Juan Veloz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Four decades into a showbiz career, high-kicking and scene-stealing are practically muscle memory for Jenifer Lewis.

item.title: Sarah Steele, of ‘The Good Fight,’ on Finding Love in Brooklyn
item.description: The actress, who plays Marissa Gold on the legal drama, fell hard for her new Brooklyn Heights co-op — and for her new partner, a lawyer.
item.dc:creator: Joanne Kaufman
item.media:credit: Regan Wood for The New York Times

item.title: Exploring Spain’s Arab Influence
item.description: Exploring the country’s Arab influence is an impossibly romantic journey, involving palaces with intricate geometric designs, castles and grand mosques reconfigured by Christians into cathedrals.
item.dc:creator: Nina Burleigh
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Emilio Parra Doiztua for The New York Times
item.media:description: Córdoba’s Mosque-Cathedral, or La Mezquita, was one of the first and grandest mosques in Europe.

item.title: How ‘the Most Vicious, Horrible Animal Alive’ Became a YouTube Star
item.description: Joseph Carter, known to his online followers as the Mink Man, trains feisty carnivores to rid canals and urban river banks of midsize pests.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang and Kim Raff
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times

item.title: Did My Cat Just Hit On Me? An Adventure in Pet Translation
item.description: Entrepreneurs are aiming to put A.I.-powered pet translation tools into our pockets.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Armlets Are Bracelets for the Biceps
item.description: Armlets have been around for thousands of years, and they’re having a modern moment in a variety of materials and styles.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Beckett
item.media:credit: Prada, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Armlets have been appearing on fashion runways, including Prada’s spring 2022 show.

item.title: Jewelry Designer Finds Inspiration in Micromosaics
item.description: Guy Bedarida’s collection of micromosaics evokes ancient scenes — and fuels his creativity as a jewelry designer.
item.dc:creator: Roxanne Robinson

item.title: Recycled Metals From Electronic Waste Used to Make Jewelry
item.description: More jewelers, large and small, are using precious metals recovered from electronic waste.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Bumpus

item.title: Talking Jewelry on TikTok
item.description: Influencers say they enjoy the experience but don’t make a lot of money from their efforts.
item.dc:creator: Melanie Abrams

item.title: For Fabio Salini, This Is a Good Time to Give Back
item.description: The Roman jeweler saw the pandemic as a call to action and so has donated jewels to an auction, with proceeds going to benefit critically ill children.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Garrahan

item.title: Review: ‘A Visible Man: A Memoir,’ by Edward Enninful
item.description: The British Vogue editor wants to make the media — and the world — a more welcoming place.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:credit: Bettmann/Corbis, via Getty Images

item.title: It’s How You Wear It
item.description: The best outfits from Summer Fridays at MoMA PS1, the Guild Hall gala and a cocktail party for Frame.
item.dc:creator: Denny Lee
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yves Mathieu East, in Frame and lots of tattoos, at the Frame party.

item.title: How Love Languages Became a Cultural Phenomenon
item.description: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Luis Mazón
item.media:credit: via Dr. Gary Chapman
item.media:description: Karolyn and Gary Chapman at their wedding reception in August 1961. The couple, who have been married for over 60 years, said they had a rocky start.

item.title: ‘Un último acto de amabilidad íntima’
item.description: Durante décadas casi no había visto a mi hermano. Pero me dejó entrar en su vida cuando quedaba poco tiempo.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Friedman
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Don’t Skip Therapy Because of Work
item.description: And other tips on asking for what you need, and making it clear when it’s a demand and not a question.
item.dc:creator: Roxane Gay
item.media:credit: Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Love Letter: Missing Your Son’s Ex-Girlfriend?
item.description: Alas, some relationships are rarely discussed.
item.dc:creator: Miya Lee

item.title: ‘It Was Magic From the First Second’
item.description: When Chelsea White, a writer and producer, first met Tash Neal, a musician, their attraction was instant. By the end of their first date, he felt “butterflies” and she found her “dream man.”
item.dc:creator: Nina Reyes
item.media:credit: Alexandra Genova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chelsea White and Tash Neal were married July 30 at the Bordone LIC in Long Island City, Queens.

item.title: At Karaoke and as a Couple, Always in Unison
item.description: Zohar Fuller and Maryse Pearce, who bonded in part over a love of theater, started dating soon after they performed a duet of “Build Me Up Buttercup” at karaoke.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: Lockdown Was Our Romantic Bubble, but Bubbles Burst
item.description: Our connection began behind masks, with eyes only, and grew so deep so fast that I began to dread a return to normal here in Shanghai.
item.dc:creator: Zhengkun Hou
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: When a Dating App Didn’t Work, an Old-Fashioned Setup Did
item.description: Shafin Fattah first encountered Luvana Chowdhury on a Muslim dating app, but she never responded when he expressed interest. Months later, at the suggestion of a mutual friend, they had a first date.
item.dc:creator: Kristen Bayrakdarian

item.title: From the First Date, Looking the Part of Husband and Wife
item.description: Caroline Hubbard and Michael McMillan II met when he ran into her at a bar. On their first date, there were already signs of a future together.
item.dc:creator: Emma Grillo

item.title: E. Bryant Crutchfield, 85, Dies; Gave the World the Trapper Keeper
item.description: His ability to blend the fun and the functional with the binder he invented brought order to the chaos of grade-school life in the 1980s and ’90s.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Bright Lights, Big City, Niche Fame
item.description: As Lower Manhattan’s most infamous publicist, Kaitlin Phillips doesn’t always stay behind the scenes.
item.dc:creator: Amy Larocca
item.media:credit: Caroline Tompkins for The New York Times
item.media:description: The publicist Kaitlin Phillips in her Manhattan apartment.

item.title: Making the Rounds on Nashville’s Singer-Songwriter Circuit
item.description: For music fans, songwriters’ nights at often unassuming venues provide an inexpensive and illuminating glimpse into Music City’s most celebrated business.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ariela Aspen, a country-pop singer and songwriter, performs during a songwriters’ night at the Commodore Grille in Nashville.

item.title: Seeking Marriage Equality for People With Disabilities
item.description: When one partner is disabled and the other isn’t, getting married could mean giving up lifesaving health care and benefits from the government.
item.dc:creator: Tammy La Gorce
item.media:credit: Clara Mokri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lori Long and Mark Contreras of Salinas, Calif., have been engaged since December 2016, but have been reluctant to marry out of fear Ms. Long would lose her health benefits.

item.title: The Public Life of the Kardashians’ Private Chef
item.description: Chef K has worked with some of the biggest celebrities. Now she’s taking center stage.
item.dc:creator: Allie Jones
item.media:credit: Carlos Jaramillo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khristianne Uy, a private chef known as Chef K, has spent the last several years working on the margins of the Kardashians. But now, she is stepping into the frame — on TikTok.

item.title: Why Andrew Tate’s Social Media Accounts Are Being Removed
item.description: TikTok, YouTube and Facebook have taken down accounts belonging to Mr. Tate, a 35-year-old British American.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: RM, BTS Leader, Embraces New Role: Art Patron
item.description: The BTS leader has been championing canonical artists from his native South Korea — studying their work, buying it and sometimes talking to it. “I feel like they’re watching me,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Russeth
item.media:credit: Dasom Han for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I think that there’s something that I can offer as an outsider of the art industry,” RM said.

item.title: Why Are My Son’s New Wife and Baby Living at Her Parents’ House?
item.description: A mother is baffled by her son and new daughter-in-law’s living arrangements, and wonders whether she should intercede.
item.dc:creator: Philip Galanes
item.media:credit: Miguel Porlan

item.title: Can an Iconic Italian Wool Survive a Changing Economy?
item.description: Casentino cloth has been finished for centuries by workers in a remote Tuscan valley. Today they are threatened by eviction.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Massimo Berruti for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibition at the Museo dell’Arte della Lana, which showcases the art of wool making, in Stia, Italy, in August.
